(i) the maximum height reached by the ball [2]
(ii) the time taken to reach maximum height [2]
examinerRemarks: Common errors: Using g = 10 m/s² without stating it. Not showing working. Incorrect significant figures.

text:
A sound wave has a frequency of 440 Hz and travels at 340 m/s in air.
(i) Calculate the wavelength of this sound wave. [2]
(ii) The sound wave enters water where its speed increases to 1500 m/s. State and explain what happens to the frequency and wavelength. [3]
markScheme:
(i) λ = v/f = 340/440 = 0.773 m (or 0.77 m)

(ii) Frequency remains the same (440 Hz) because frequency is determined by the source, not the medium.
Wavelength increases because λ = v/f, and v increases while f stays constant.
New wavelength = 1500/440 = 3.41 m
examinerRemarks: Many candidates incorrectly stated that frequency changes when wave enters new medium. Remember: frequency is determined by the SOURCE.

A cell of e.m.f. 1.5 V and internal resistance 0.50 Ω is connected to an external resistance of 2.5 Ω.
(i) Calculate the current in the circuit. [2]
(ii) Calculate the terminal potential difference across the cell. [2]
(iii) Calculate the power dissipated in the external resistance. [2]
examinerRemarks: Some candidates confused e.m.f. with terminal p.d. Remember: e.m.f. = terminal p.d. + lost volts (Ir)

text:
A radioactive isotope has a half-life of 5.0 days. A sample initially contains 8.0 × 10¹⁰ atoms.
(i) Calculate the decay constant λ. [2]
(ii) Calculate the initial activity of the sample. [2]
(iii) Calculate the number of atoms remaining after 15 days. [2]
examinerRemarks: Ensure units are consistent. If using λ in s⁻¹, time must be in seconds. Common error: forgetting to convert days to seconds.

text:
A fixed mass of an ideal gas occupies a volume of 2.0 × 10⁻³ m³ at a pressure of 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa and temperature of 300 K.
(i) The gas is heated at constant pressure until its volume doubles. Calculate the final temperature. [2]
(ii) Calculate the work done by the gas during this expansion. [2]
(iii) State and explain what happens to the internal energy of the gas. [2]
markScheme:
(i) At constant pressure: V₁/T₁ = V₂/T₂
2.0 × 10⁻³/300 = 4.0 × 10⁻³/T₂
T₂ = 600 K

(ii) W = pΔV = 1.0 × 10⁵ × (4.0 - 2.0) × 10⁻³ = 200 J

(iii) Internal energy increases because temperature increases.
For an ideal gas, internal energy depends only on temperature (U ∝ T for ideal gas).
examinerRemarks: Remember: For an ideal gas at constant pressure, V ∝ T (Charles's Law). Internal energy of ideal gas depends ONLY on temperature.
